<@U01EGU2HJ87> <@U01EP8RNY9L> There was a request (from your end, actually) to record the talks. Are you folks OK with that?

elements.text: There was a request (from your end, actually) to record the talks. Are you folks OK with that?

text: It would be nice to do this conference discussion in Surface Fleet!

elements.text: It would be nice to do this conference discussion in Surface Fleet!

text: This demo is so cool! Any thoughts on how to avoid unintentional overwriting when multiple users are editing content, and support some kind of versioning, incl. forks & rollback?

elements.text: This demo is so cool! Any thoughts on how to avoid unintentional overwriting when multiple users are editing content, and support some kind of versioning, incl. forks & rollback?

text: Age-old question (subject of n HPTS conferences during Jim Gray’s life): Why are the Queue and the DB separate? Should one be other or vice versa?

elements.text: Age-old question (subject of n HPTS conferences during Jim Gray’s life): Why are the Queue and the DB separate? Should one be other or vice versa?

text: The weak language binding of Ambrosia is also an ordered execution contract. Does this mean we cannot replace an immortal with a distributed version of the immortal?

elements.text: The weak language binding of Ambrosia is also an ordered execution contract. Does this mean we cannot replace an immortal with a distributed version of the immortal?

text: Or rather, a distributed version is required to preserve order (via coordination)?

elements.text: Or rather, a distributed version is required to preserve order (via coordination)?

text: One thing we can agree on — the popular FaaS frameworks can be very inefficient if you push them outside their comfort zone.

elements.text: One thing we can agree on — the popular FaaS frameworks can be very inefficient if you push them outside their comfort zone.

text: The performance question for Ambrosia that I’d like to see stress-tested is log write latency — this is the coordination bottleneck inherent in the design, no? Can we avoid a linear log and get better latency (and more throughput)? And how this compares to similar efforts like Corfu.

elements.text: The performance question for Ambrosia that I’d like to see stress-tested is log write latency — this is the coordination bottleneck inherent in the design, no? Can we avoid a linear log and get better latency (and more throughput)? And how this compares to similar efforts like Corfu.

text: This is a much more "meta" question, the ideas of virtual resiliency echo a lot of the desires of Orleans with their virtual actors. The most major differerence that I see is the role that state plays in Ambrosia vs Orleans. State management has to be explicit in Orleans (even if the "computation" is virtually resilient). In Ambrosia, virtual resiliency encompasses state. Is that correct?

elements.text: This is a much more "meta" question, the ideas of virtual resiliency echo a lot of the desires of Orleans with their virtual actors. The most major differerence that I see is the role that state plays in Ambrosia vs Orleans. State management has to be explicit in Orleans (even if the "computation" is virtually resilient). In Ambrosia, virtual resiliency encompasses state. Is that correct?

text: Sorry I was not able to join the Zoom call in time... I have too many things going on these days. Happy to field any questions though, at least asynchronously! We have a lot of ideas to take these user experiences much further, such as through real-time sharing of sensor data across federations of devices. This can take certain forms of "sharing" from actions that take 15-30s (e.g. for Screen Sharing in Teams calls) to things that can happen in 10s, 1s, even <1s in socially nuanced ways by moving and tilting devices (as just one example).  Our recent work on tilt-responsive interfaces has strong hints in this direction... <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bovY2IdTbgE>

attachments.title: Tilt-Responsive Techniques for Digital Drawing Boards
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Tilt-Responsive Techniques for Digital Drawing Boards
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bovY2IdTbgE?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

elements.text: Sorry I was not able to join the Zoom call in time... I have too many things going on these days. Happy to field any questions though, at least asynchronously! We have a lot of ideas to take these user experiences much further, such as through real-time sharing of sensor data across federations of devices. This can take certain forms of "sharing" from actions that take 15-30s (e.g. for Screen Sharing in Teams calls) to things that can happen in 10s, 1s, even <1s in socially nuanced ways by moving and tilting devices (as just one example).  Our recent work on tilt-responsive interfaces has strong hints in this direction...

text: In a distributed setting like Durable Functions + FASTER, what are the consistency guarantees offered?

elements.text: In a distributed setting like Durable Functions + FASTER, what are the consistency guarantees offered?

text: Shadowfax latency?

elements.text: Shadowfax latency?

text: We found plenty of bandwidth at AWS for remote Anna clients, but latency became an issue.

elements.text: We found plenty of bandwidth at AWS for remote Anna clients, but latency became an issue.

text: Does CPR say anything about interleavings across clients? And is there dataflow/visibility across clients? It looks to be a per-client guarantee from the cartoon, but probably I’m misunderstanding.

elements.text: Does CPR say anything about interleavings across clients? And is there dataflow/visibility across clients? It looks to be a per-client guarantee from the cartoon, but probably I’m misunderstanding.

text: More generally, we should sort out the consistency guarantees offered by DPR wrt the guarantees of Cloudburst/Hydrocache work.

elements.text: More generally, we should sort out the consistency guarantees offered by DPR wrt the guarantees of Cloudburst/Hydrocache work.

text: Is it correct to think of prefix consistency as causal consistency, where the dependency is the prefix, and you can change dependencies by changing the session?

elements.text: Is it correct to think of prefix consistency as causal consistency, where the dependency is the prefix, and you can change dependencies by changing the session?

text: The Hydrocache work in SIGMOD 20 (and Natacha has prior work) provides Transactional Causal Consistency. I’d like to understand how that relates to prefix consistency.

elements.text: The Hydrocache work in SIGMOD 20 (and Natacha has prior work) provides Transactional Causal Consistency. I’d like to understand how that relates to prefix consistency.

text: Yes, there is clearly a latency-throughput tradeoff for performance. We do small batches (32KB-128KB) to keep latency manageable. Shadowfax uses larger batches, but in DPR + FASTER work, we get 100 microseconds of latency (within cluster) with 10+ million ops/sec.

elements.text: Yes, there is clearly a latency-throughput tradeoff for performance. We do small batches (32KB-128KB) to keep latency manageable. Shadowfax uses larger batches, but in DPR + FASTER work, we get 100 microseconds of latency (within cluster) with 10+ million ops/sec.

text: That would be a succinct way of thinking about it, yes. You can introduce other client-aware dependencies in the model, but sessions are the unit for corralling dependencies.

elements.text: That would be a succinct way of thinking about it, yes. You can introduce other client-aware dependencies in the model, but sessions are the unit for corralling dependencies.

text: Assuming this is the prefix consistency I'm familiar with, from a client's local view of the final linear order of operations consists of a prefix of the final linear order and its own set of "pending operations".  A nice benefit of this is it's a total order, just with gaps where unknown operations may slot in.

elements.text: Assuming this is the prefix consistency I'm familiar with, from a client's local view of the final linear order of operations consists of a prefix of the final linear order and its own set of "pending operations".  A nice benefit of this is it's a total order, just with gaps where unknown operations may slot in.

text: is this property true of the prefix consistency we're talking about here?

elements.text: is this property true of the prefix consistency we're talking about here?

text: Yes, the notion of prefix consistency has definitely been around for decades. Our SIGMOD 2019 work showed how prefix consistency is achievable without blocking in a concurrent multi-threaded node. The distributed extension takes this concept to sessions that span machines. We had to be very careful to retain the 10-100 million ops/sec performance in this setting, so the tracking had to be made lightweight.

elements.text: Yes, the notion of prefix consistency has definitely been around for decades. Our SIGMOD 2019 work showed how prefix consistency is achievable without blocking in a concurrent multi-threaded node. The distributed extension takes this concept to sessions that span machines. We had to be very careful to retain the 10-100 million ops/sec performance in this setting, so the tracking had to be made lightweight.

text: Our individual operations in a session are single shard - they might be "transactions", but they are each not distributed.

elements.text: Our individual operations in a session are single shard - they might be "transactions", but they are each not distributed.

text: How does Shadowfax handle failures? Does it depend on some sort of leader election like Paxos, or is there some timeout-based spawning of new leaders? In the 2nd case, how do you prevent 2 leaders from writing simultaneously?

elements.text: How does Shadowfax handle failures? Does it depend on some sort of leader election like Paxos, or is there some timeout-based spawning of new leaders? In the 2nd case, how do you prevent 2 leaders from writing simultaneously?

text: We have an orthogonal cluster manager (like Kubernetes or Service Fabric) to manage failures and respawning of cluster machines. Further, there is only a single writer to the shared part of the FasterLog shard (on cloud storage) at a time, governed by write lock provided by the cloud storage service.

elements.text: We have an orthogonal cluster manager (like Kubernetes or Service Fabric) to manage failures and respawning of cluster machines. Further, there is only a single writer to the shared part of the FasterLog shard (on cloud storage) at a time, governed by write lock provided by the cloud storage service.

text: You get causal consistency for the workflow, with logging (using FasterLog) as an underlying mechanism.

elements.text: You get causal consistency for the workflow, with logging (using FasterLog) as an underlying mechanism.

text: It's not something we've tackled yet, but definitely makes sense :)

elements.text: It's not something we've tackled yet, but definitely makes sense :)

text: Fair enough. I guess a lot also depends on why the queue is being used. In a lot of cloud contexts, queues are being used to create recoverability, which should, in my opinion, be a built-in platform feature...

elements.text: Fair enough. I guess a lot also depends on why the queue is being used. In a lot of cloud contexts, queues are being used to create recoverability, which should, in my opinion, be a built-in platform feature...

text: Exactly, well stated Matthew! In the original paper we had the notion of "strict CPR", where we forced there to be no holes as part of the protocol. We have since expanded to a version we called "relaxed CPR", where clients have a pending set as a first class citizen. The latter is important when sessions may become idle with pending operations, or if you have long I/O times (e.g., with remote) that could delay commit.

elements.text: Exactly, well stated Matthew! In the original paper we had the notion of "strict CPR", where we forced there to be no holes as part of the protocol. We have since expanded to a version we called "relaxed CPR", where clients have a pending set as a first class citizen. The latter is important when sessions may become idle with pending operations, or if you have long I/O times (e.g., with remote) that could delay commit.

text: Yes, the DPR model provide guarantees within a session. Across sessions, consistency is governed by the individual cache-store's commit implementation. (Recall that there is only one copy of a given data item.)

elements.text: Yes, the DPR model provide guarantees within a session. Across sessions, consistency is governed by the individual cache-store's commit implementation. (Recall that there is only one copy of a given data item.)

text: You absolutely could. There are likely different ways of going about this. A good start, from my point of view, is to make a "sharded" version, Orleans style, which supports elastic scalability in a highly available, performant manner. I think I see your point, though, that you might be able to get away with a less "semantically partitioned" approach using the stuff you've developed.

elements.text: You absolutely could. There are likely different ways of going about this. A good start, from my point of view, is to make a "sharded" version, Orleans style, which supports elastic scalability in a highly available, performant manner. I think I see your point, though, that you might be able to get away with a less "semantically partitioned" approach using the stuff you've developed.

text: And there's a lot of latent opportunity outside that zone IMO

elements.text: And there's a lot of latent opportunity outside that zone IMO

text: Log write throughput is practically unlimited in the datacenter, by using RAID style arrays of managed disks (per VM), combined with the adaptive batching mechanisms. We easily get many GB of throughput/s from a single VM in configurations like these. The bottleneck is typically the time it takes to run actual code. This is what I meant by log activity is request bound rather than state change bound. 1GB of incoming requests results in 1GB of log writing, regardless of how much state is changed by executing the request. With cost being limited these days by CPU, the extra log movement and writing is very cheap. Even the cost of contention associated with writing to the tail of the log is typically very dominated by deserialization and request execution time in practice.

elements.text: Log write throughput is practically unlimited in the datacenter, by using RAID style arrays of managed disks (per VM), combined with the adaptive batching mechanisms. We easily get many GB of throughput/s from a single VM in configurations like these. The bottleneck is typically the time it takes to run actual code. This is what I meant by log activity is request bound rather than state change bound. 1GB of incoming requests results in 1GB of log writing, regardless of how much state is changed by executing the request. With cost being limited these days by CPU, the extra log movement and writing is very cheap. Even the cost of contention associated with writing to the tail of the log is typically very dominated by deserialization and request execution time in practice.

text: In terms of latency, we are limited by the time to make a request durable in a replicated environment. Today, this latency is 100s of microseconds within the datacenter. At the time the paper was written, that storage service hadn't been made available yet. I suspect we could get under a millisecond with the latest. Across datacenters, of course, will be significantly larger, although we haven't measured.

elements.text: In terms of latency, we are limited by the time to make a request durable in a replicated environment. Today, this latency is 100s of microseconds within the datacenter. At the time the paper was written, that storage service hadn't been made available yet. I suspect we could get under a millisecond with the latest. Across datacenters, of course, will be significantly larger, although we haven't measured.

text: I just realized that there may have been a misunderstanding in the talk about the log. Communicating immortals no NOT share a log. They each have their own independent logs. So if you manually sharded an easily partitioned service, each shard would get it's own log, and be coordination free.

elements.text: I just realized that there may have been a misunderstanding in the talk about the log. Communicating immortals no NOT share a log. They each have their own independent logs. So if you manually sharded an easily partitioned service, each shard would get it's own log, and be coordination free.

text: Orleans doesn't have virtual resiliency today. Logically failure free execution can be guaranteed in a manner similar to what I described for Azure functions in the talk. For instance, application writers must explicitly save and restore state, must have their own logic (e.g. using seq nos) to guarantee logically exactly once execution, and generally write their code with partial executions in mind. I believe it does have a transaction mechanism, though, which can be used to atomically commit large blocks of code, which helps with writing code against partial executions, although at high cost, and still requires developer intervention.

elements.text: Orleans doesn't have virtual resiliency today. Logically failure free execution can be guaranteed in a manner similar to what I described for Azure functions in the talk. For instance, application writers must explicitly save and restore state, must have their own logic (e.g. using seq nos) to guarantee logically exactly once execution, and generally write their code with partial executions in mind. I believe it does have a transaction mechanism, though, which can be used to atomically commit large blocks of code, which helps with writing code against partial executions, although at high cost, and still requires developer intervention.

text: Ambrosia covers both logical exactly once execution, and state recovery, which is a minimum for supporting virtual resiliency.

elements.text: Ambrosia covers both logical exactly once execution, and state recovery, which is a minimum for supporting virtual resiliency.

text: It also automatically recovers all connections to other Ambrosia immortals, even if the IP address, or operating system, or CPU changes.

elements.text: It also automatically recovers all connections to other Ambrosia immortals, even if the IP address, or operating system, or CPU changes.
